intro: Mouroucoa nicaraguensis, commonly known as the Nicaraguan sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Central America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and related grass-like plants. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Its slender, triangular stems are often densely packed, forming dense clumps or tussocks. The flowers are small and inconspicuous, arranged in spikelets, and it plays a role in wetland ecosystems by stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various organisms.
